statement.text: Type 2 endoleak embolization can be performed via transarterial approach (accessing feeding vessels through arterial circulation) or translumbar approach (direct percutaneous puncture of aneurysm sac), using coils and/or liquid embolic agents to occlude the endoleak circuit.
statement.formal: Embolization: [Transarterial (via collaterals) OR Translumbar (direct sac puncture)] + [Coils AND/OR Liquid embolic] → Endoleak occlusion (60-85% success, 20-40% recurrence)

explanation.intuition: Embolization is like plugging a leak by either (1) going through the plumbing system to reach the leak (transarterial), or (2) sticking a needle directly through the wall to the leak (translumbar). You fill the space with metal coils or liquid glue to block blood flow.
explanation.key_insight: The key to successful Type 2 embolization is treating BOTH inflow and outflow vessels. If you only plug the inflow, blood can still enter through the outflow vessel running backward. This is why identifying the complete endoleak circuit is critical.
explanation.technical_details: Success rates vary by approach: transarterial 60-70%, translumbar 70-85%, but translumbar has higher complication risk. Recurrence is common (20-40%) because collateral vessels can recruit new pathways. Liquid embolic agents (Onyx, n-BCA) may provide better sac penetration than coils alone.

catheter_selection: Microcatheter (2.8F) for selective branch vessel cannulation
target_identification: Common targets: Iliolumbar artery → Lumbar arteries
IMA via SMA and marginal artery
embolization_sequence: 2. Advance microcatheter as close to sac as possible
3. Deploy coils from distal to proximal ('sandwich technique')
4. Or inject liquid embolic with flow arrest

advantages: Can treat multiple vessels in one session
disadvantages: May not reach all vessels (anatomic limitations)
Incomplete occlusion if can't reach sac
success_factors: Ability to advance catheter to sac

embolization_technique: Remove needle when sac densely packed

contraindications: Bowel interposed between sac and back

coils.deployment_strategy: Pack densely from distal to proximal to prevent migration

onyx.composition: Ethylene vinyl alcohol copolymer in DMSO

combination_approach.rationale: Coils provide scaffold, liquid embolic fills interstices
combination_approach.technique: Deploy coils first, then inject liquid embolic through coil mass
combination_approach.evidence: Some studies show improved durability vs. coils alone

pre_procedure: Review CTA to map vessels and plan approach
follow_up_imaging: CTA at 1 month to assess technical success
Success defined as: Endoleak resolved + Sac stable/decreased

technical_success.definition: Completion angiogram shows no residual endoleak filling

clinical_success.definition: Endoleak resolved on CT + Sac stable or decreased

reintervention.approaches: Can alternate or combine transarterial and translumbar

decision_algorithm.second_line: Translumbar if transarterial fails or not feasible
decision_algorithm.hybrid_approach: Some operators do translumbar primarily for faster, more complete occlusion

sources.citation: Society of Interventional Radiology Standards of Practice for Type 2 Endoleak
Handbook of Interventional Radiologic Procedures, 5th Edition
Embolization of Type 2 Endoleaks: Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
sources.journal: Journal of Vascular and Interventional Radiology

learning_objectives: Compare transarterial and translumbar embolization approaches
Select appropriate embolic agents for Type 2 endoleaks
clinical_pearls: Always embolize BOTH inflow and outflow vessels - incomplete treatment = recurrence
Translumbar is more invasive but often more effective - consider first-line for complex cases
Liquid embolic (Onyx) may have lower recurrence than coils alone
20-40% recurrence is expected - set patient expectations appropriately
CT at 1 month tells you technical success; 6-12 months tells you clinical success
